messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help with tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, ok these were my guesses, and they are just my guesses, interested to hear what others think. A, Kanayama, very simular in style to the Mid Muromachi
messages.messageBody:
Hi all, ok these were my guesses, and they are just my guesses, interested to hear what others think.
A, Kanayama, very simular in style to the Mid Muromachi works.

B, Nara, Old school so Ko-Nara ( still not sure about this though, that was my first thought )

C, Kanayama, or maybe Owari

D, Ito maybe.

That was my tsuba kantei for the day :-).
how did I score.

Rich T

----- Original Message -----
From: alchemyst
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 23, 2003 12:56 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Help with tsuba id


I tried to get some opinions on these tsuba on that
other group, but the bs was too much. Perhaps someone
can suggest an attribution on a couple of these??

http://gcclearn.gcc.vccs.edu/stein/tsuba4.jpg

Thanks
Rich
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

messages.subject: Re: Help with tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: ... Jim - Thanks for the input, I understand the problem of remote attributions :-)  On the inlay tsuba, is there a special name for that type of high relief
messages.messageBody:
> It's also very unusual to see such a thin plate on the inlaid piece.
> Interesting pieces.
>
> Jim

Jim -

Thanks for the input, I understand the problem of
"remote" attributions :-) On the inlay tsuba,
is there a special name for that type of high
relief (3D) work where the zogan almost sits on
top of the plate and is really rounded? Any
school specializze in that type of inlay?

Thanks
Rich
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...

The Japanese Sword Index
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm
http://home.earthlink.net/~steinrl/nihonto.htm
------------------------------------------------------------

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Help with tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The sukashi pieces certainly have Kanayama-esq designs, but in this case I have to agree with Cary s comment the other day about difficulty (futility?)
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The sukashi pieces certainly have Kanayama-esq designs, but in this case I
have to agree with Cary's comment the other day about difficulty (futility?)
of identifying them without seeing the iron in person. I think that 3 or 4
mm would be unusually thin for Kanayama or even Owari work.

It's also very unusual to see such a thin plate on the inlaid piece.
Interesting pieces.

Jim

> I tried to get some opinions on these tsuba on that
> other group, but the bs was too much. Perhaps someone
> can suggest an attribution on a couple of these??
>
> http://gcclearn.gcc.vccs.edu/stein/tsuba4.jpg
>
> Thanks
> Rich

messages.subject: Re: Help with tsuba id
messages.msgSnippet: ... interested to hear what others think. ... I would love it to be Kanayama :-) I think maybe Owari or Shoami. ... that was my first thought That s what I
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@w...>
wrote:
> Hi all, ok these were my guesses, and they are just my guesses,
interested to hear what others think.
> A, Kanayama, very simular in style to the Mid Muromachi works.

I would love it to be Kanayama :-) I think maybe Owari or Shoami.

> B, Nara, Old school so Ko-Nara ( still not sure about this though,
that was my first thought

That's what I think also, but the inlay (really more onlay)
is really 3-D. It's like the wire, leaves and beads are
on top of the plate. Don't know if Nara did that.

> C, Kanayama, or maybe Owari

I think possibly either.

> D, Ito maybe.

I'm guessing either katchushi or Shoami.

>
> That was my tsuba kantei for the day :-).
> how did I score.
>
> Rich T

Thanks for the suggestions.

Rich S
------------------------------------------------------------
Richard Stein, PhD alchemyst@...
